abstract: Melioidosis is a severe infectious disease caused by the saprophytic facultative intracellular pathogen Burkholderia pseudomallei. The disease is endemic in Southeast Asia and Northern Australia, and no effective vaccine exists. To describe human cell-mediated immune responses to B. pseudomallei and to identify candidate antigens for vaccine development, the ability of antigen-pulsed monocyte-derived dendritic cells (moDCs) to trigger autologous T-cell responses to B. pseudomallei and its products was tested. moDCs were prepared from healthy individuals exposed or not exposed to B. pseudomallei, based on serological evidence. These were pulsed with heat-killed B. pseudomallei or purified antigens, including ABC transporters (LolC, OppA, and PotF), Bsa type III secreted proteins (BipD and BopE), tandem repeat sequence-containing proteins (Rp1 and Rp2), flagellin, and heat shock proteins (Hsp60 and Hsp70), prior to being mixed with autologous T-cell populations. After pulsing of cells with either heat-killed B. pseudomallei, LolC, or Rp2, coculturing the antigen-pulsed moDCs with T cells elicited gamma interferon production from CD4+ T cells from seropositive donors at levels greater than those for seronegative donors. These antigens also induced granzyme B (cytotoxic) responses from CD8+ T cells. Activation of antigen-specific CD4+ T cells required direct contact with moDCs and was therefore not dependent on soluble mediators. Rp peptide epitopes recognized by T cells in healthy individuals were identified. Our study provides valuable novel data on the induction of human cell-mediated immune responses to B. pseudomallei and its protein antigens that may be exploited in the rational development of vaccines to combat melioidosis

Abstract 1 
Melioidosis is a severe infectious disease caused by the saprophytic facultative 2 
intracellular pathogen Burkholderia pseudomallei. The disease is endemic in 3 
Southeast Asia and Northern Australia and no effective vaccine exists. To describe 4 
human cell-mediated immune responses to B. pseudomallei and to identify candidate 5 
antigens for vaccine development, the ability of antigen-pulsed monocyte-derived 6 
dendritic cells (moDCs) to trigger autologous T cell responses to B. pseudomallei and 7 
its products was tested. MoDC were prepared from healthy individuals exposed or not 8 
exposed to B. pseudomallei based on serological evidence. These were pulsed with 9 
heat-killed B. pseudomallei or purified antigens including ABC transporters (LolC, 10 
OppA and PotF), Bsa type III secreted proteins (BipD and BopE), tandem repeated 11 
sequence proteins (Rp1 and Rp2), flagellin and heat shock proteins (Hsp60 and 12 
Hsp70) prior to mixing with autologous T cell populations. After pulsing with either 13 
heat-killed B. pseudomallei or LolC or Rp2, co-culturing the antigen-pulsed moDC 14 
with T cells elicited interferon-gamma production of CD4+ T cells from seropositive 15 
donors at levels greater than seronegative donors. These antigens also induced 16 
granzyme B (cytotoxic) responses from CD8+ T cells. Activation of antigen-specific 17 
CD4+ T cells required direct contact with moDC and is therefore not dependent on 18 
soluble mediators. Peptide epitopes of the Rp proteins recognized by T cells in 19 
healthy individuals were identified. Our study provides valuable novel data on the 20 
induction of human cell-mediated immune responses to B. pseudomallei and its 21 
protein antigens that may be exploited in the rational development of vaccines to 22 
combat melioidosis. 23

Introduction 1 
Burkholderia pseudomallei is a Gram-negative facultative intracellular bacterium 2 
that causes melioidosis, a severe invasive disease that is endemic in Southeast Asia, 3 
Northern Australia and several other tropical regions (7, 32). Acute septic melioidosis 4 
has a high mortality rate in Northeast Thailand (approximately 50%), even in patients 5 
that receive appropriate antibiotics. Serological evidence, based on the indirect 6 
hemagglutination assay (IHA), indicates that 80% of people living in endemic areas 7 
have been exposed to B. pseudomallei with no clinical symptoms and the prevalence 8 
of positive serology increases with age (4, 9). Recurrent melioidosis can also occur 9 
either as relapse after antibiotic treatment or re-infection (21). B. pseudomallei is 10 
classified as a NIAID category B potential agent for biological terrorism (24). The 11 
mechanisms by which the organism evades the bactericidal effects of the host immune 12 
response are not fully understood and there are no licensed vaccines at the time of 13 
writing. 14 
Recently, we used a B. pseudomallei protein microarray to identify proteins of the 15 
organism recognized by the human humoral immune system (13). However, 16 
development of effective melioidosis vaccines also requires consideration of the cell-17 
mediated immune response owing to intracellular persistence of the bacterium. In 18 
animal models, the crucial mediator of resistance to acute B. pseudomallei infection is 19 
IFN-γ produced by multiple cell types  including NK cells, and both CD4 and CD8 T-20 
cells (17, 20, 26). T-cell-mediated responses to some recombinant proteins of B. 21 
pseudomallei have been studied. Immunization of mice with a live-attenuated ilvI 22 
mutant of B. pseudomallei (2D2), induced antigen-specific T-cells, including CD4+ T-23 
cells that respond to proteins secreted by the Bsa type III secretion system (T3SS; 24 
BopE and BipD) (16). B. pseudomallei 2D2-primed T-cells also recognize bacterial 25 
 5 
proteins of the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) family, including LolC, PotF and OppA, 1 
and respond by producing IFN-γ (18). In an assay to evaluate candidate vaccine 2 
antigens, immunization of mice with adjuvant-mixed Bip proteins did not elicit 3 
protection against  B. pseudomallei infection (11, 27). However, antibodies to BipB, 4 
BipC and BipD are detected in serum of melioidosis patients (11, 28). Further, a DNA 5 
vaccine encoding the flagellin protein and CpG motifs enhanced resistance of 6 
immunized mice to B. pseudomallei (5, 6). Owing to the incomplete protection 7 
afforded by candidate antigens to date, it is necessary to search for additional proteins 8 
for vaccine development. Tandem repeated sequence proteins of B. pseudomallei 9 
(such as Rp1 and Rp2) may be considered as vaccine candidates, as proteins 10 
containing tandem repeats (TR) are known targets of B-cell responses (15). Heat 11 
shock proteins (HSPs) are also found to play a role in intracellular antigen processing 12 
and presentation, and cross-presentation (36). Indeed a DNA vaccine encoding a BCG 13 
heat-shock protein could enhance T-cell activation against mycobacterial infection 14 
(19). The HSPs of B. pseudomallei have not been studied for vaccine development to 15 
date.  16 
DCs are the control centre of the immune system and are specialized antigen-17 
presenting cells that regulate the initiation of T-cell responses to eradicate invading 18 
pathogens (31). In mice, immunization with DCs pulsed with heat-killed B. 19 
pseudomallei in the presence of CpG adjuvant led to the induction of both cell-20 
mediated and humoral responses to the organism (12). However, little is known about 21 
the biology of DCs in relation to B. pseudomallei antigens and the generation of 22 
effective T-cell immunity in humans. In a previous study, we determined the ability of 23 
ABC transporter proteins LolC, OppA and PotF to restimulate T-cells in whole blood 24 
or PBMC from seropositive healthy humans and recovered melioidosis patients living 25 
 6 
in areas where melioidosis is endemic (29). Here, we have extended these 1 
observations by examining the ability of B. pseudomallei and a panel of its antigens to 2 
pulse human monocyte-derived dendritic cells (moDCs) to stimulate autologous T-3 
cell populations in vitro.  4 
Our data show that autologous human DCs efficiently processed and presented 5 
heat-killed B. pseudomallei and its purified antigens to CD4 T-cells and to a lesser 6 
extent CD8 T-cells in a contact-dependent manner. Using this approach, tandem 7 
repeat sequence proteins were found to be novel T-cell immunogens of B. 8 
pseudomallei. We provide novel data on the B. pseudomallei antigens presented by 9 
human DC, some of which are candidates for inclusion into vaccines to elicit cell-10 
mediated immunity against melioidosis. 11

Material and Methods 1 
Human subjects  2 
The consent form for the study was approved by the Khon Kaen University Ethics 3 
Committee for Human Research (project number HE470506). All subjects signed the 4 
consent form and the data collected was not disclosed. Leukocyte-rich samples from 5 
healthy blood donors were collected as leftover samples from the Blood Transfusion 6 
Center, Faculty of Medicine, Khon Kaen University. The healthy subjects were 7 
divided into either seronegative or seropositive groups based on titers of antibody to 8 
B. pseudomallei quantified by IHA. Seronegative subjects were  selected on the basis 9 
of IHA titers lower 1:40  whereas the seropositive subjects presumed to have been 10 
exposed to B. pseudomallei were selected by titers of 1:40 or greater (8). Both the 11 
seronegative and seropositive donors were age-matched and had no clinical history of 12 
melioidosis but live in an endemic area of melioidosis (predominantly the Northeast 13 
of Thailand). 14 
 15 
Monocyte-derived dendritic cells (moDCs) 16 
Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) were isolated by Ficoll-Hypaque 17 
density gradient centrifugation of leukocyte-rich samples. Monocytes (CD14+), CD4+ 18 
and CD8+ T-cells were then isolated by positive selection using immunomagnetic 19 
beads (Miltenyi Biotec, Germany) and their purity determined by flow cytometry as 20 
described below.  Immature DC were generated from monocytes by culture in 300 21 
U/ml of  granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) (Preprotech, 22 
USA) and 200 U/ml of interleukin-4 (IL-4) (Preprotech, USA) for 6 days  in 1 ml of 23 
complete RPMI 1640 (RPMI 1640 containing 10% (v/v) heat-inactivated fetal bovine 24 
serum (FBS), 100U/ml penicillin, 100µg/ml streptomycin and 2mM L-glutamine; 25 
 8 
Sigma-Aldrich, USA). Every two days, 500 µl of culture supernatant was removed 1 
and 500 µl of fresh culture medium containing cytokines at the same final 2 
concentrations added.  3 
 4 
Proteins and peptides   5 
LolC, OppA and PotF polypeptides lacking predicted membrane-spanning 6 
domains were expressed in E. coli under kanamycin selection, and purified as 7 
previously described (18).  Expression and purification of BipD and BopE proteins in 8 
E. coli has been described elsewhere (16). The full-length B. pseudomallei Hsp60 9 
(BpHsp60), Hsp70 (BpHsp70), and flagellin (Flg) genes were cloned and expressed 10 
E. coli M15 cells and purified as described (34). Rp proteins and peptides were 11

Discussion 1 
B. pseudomallei causes severe invasive infections with a high mortality rate in 2 
endemic areas. Recent studies have begun to unravel the bacterial constituents and 3 
host responses required for control of melioidosis. For example, we identified protein 4 
targets of human antibody responses using protein microarrays (13). However, the 5 
development of effective vaccines for B. pseudomallei likely requires cell-mediated 6 
immunity owing to the ability of the pathogen to persist for protracted periods in an 7 
intracellular niche. In a previous study, we applied a whole blood assay (WBA) to 8 
explore human cellular responses to the pathogen, demonstrating the priming of B. 9 
pseudomallei reactive T-cells in healthy individuals living in the endemic region of 10 
NE Thailand. However, such assays  do not  examine the APC-T-cell interactions 11 
required for successful immune responses and give high background levels of IFN-γ 12 
due to the presence of NK cells  (29). In an effort to circumvent these issues, heat-13 
killed bacteria and ten purified proteins of the pathogen were evaluated for their 14 
ability to stimulate T-cell responses when presented by autologous moDCs.  15 
DCs are professional antigen-presenting cells and play a central role in initiating 16 
T-cell responses. Evidence exists that B. pseudomallei infected-human moDCs are 17 
able to induces T-cell differentiation toward a Th1 population in a manner dependent 18 
upon cytokine production (3). Our study revealed that moDCs pulsed with heat-killed 19 
B. pseudomallei or recombinant protein antigens predominantly stimulated IFN-γ 20 
production by CD4+ rather than CD8+ T-cells ex vivo. After HkBp stimulation, IFN-γ 21 
producing cells from seropositive subjects responded to a much greater extent when 22 
compared with seronegative subjects from the endemic area. In seropositive donors, 23 
IFN-γ production from CD4+ T-cells was considerably higher than that from CD8+ T-24 
 21 
cells. This result is consistent with previous data that  induction of IFN-γ in response 1 
to the organism is elevated in seropositive donors (1, 29).  2 
The important role of CD4+ T-cells has been demonstrated in a mouse model of 3 
melioidosis, where antigen-specific CD4+ T-cells were  induced by infection with a 4 
live-attenuated B. pseudomallei mutant and correlated with protection against 5 
secondary infection (16, 17). The role of CD4+ T-cells in human melioidosis is less 6 
clear, since HIV/AIDS is apparently not a risk factor for melioidosis (10). 7 
Nevertheless, our findings confirm that exposure to B. pseudomallei clearly results in 8 
priming of a robust T-cell response as CD4+ T-cells from seropositive individuals 9 
respond to moDC pulsed with HkBp by producing high levels of IFN-γ. This was 10 
consistent with our previous study in whole blood cultures that revealed an 11 
association between the secretion of IFN-γ from antigen-specific T-cells in response 12 
to the pathogen or its ABC transporter proteins (LolC, OppA and PotF) and increasing 13 
antibody titers (29). To further identify antigens that may be involved in this process, 14 
we confirmed the immunogenicity of ABC transporter proteins and screened new 15 
purified proteins, some of which are associated with B. pseudomallei virulence, for 16 
their ability to stimulate human T-cells when presented by moDC. This revealed that 17 
the newly defined Rp2 protein elicited significantly higher IFN-γ responses in primed 18 
CD4+ T-cells, compared to controls. 19 
In addition,  CD4+ T-cells of some responders from the seropositive group could 20 
produce IFN-γ at levels above the mean in response to the other proteins tested 21 
including ABC transporter proteins (OppA and PotF), T3SS proteins (BipD and 22 
BopE), heat shock proteins (Hsp60, and Hsp70), tandem repeated protein Rp1, and 23 
flagellin. These results suggested that there were 2 groups of seropositive individuals 24 
who were relatively high and low responders to B. pseudomallei. Meanwhile, CD4+ 25 
 22 
T-cells reactive to purified BipD and BopE have been detected following 1 
immunization of mice, however in murine models immunization with BipD or other 2 
predicted components of the Bsa type III secretion apparatus has not elicited 3 
significant protection against acute melioidosis (11, 27). Conversely, recombinant 4 
flagellin could provide limited protection in mice albeit not as great as when used 5 
given as a plasmid DNA vaccine or with specific adjuvants such as CpG  (5, 6, 30). 6 
Recombinant Hsp, especially Hsp70, can induce T-cell responses due to the flagellin 7 
contamination (34). It remains possible that other T3SS, flagella or Hsp-related 8 
proteins may induce protective human cell-mediated immunity or that responses to 9 
existing antigens characterized to date may be rationally improved using novel 10 
delivery or adjuvant strategies.  11 
In a whole blood assay, NK cells, CD4+ T-cells and CD8+ T-cells from subjects 12 
exposed to B. pseudomallei respond to HkBp by rapidly producing IFN-γ (29). In 13 
such assays, it is possible that the response could be cytokine-dependent and 14 
independent of the TCR pathway. By using a Transwell system to prevent cell contact 15 
but permit diffusion of soluble mediators, we observed that the dominant response of 16 
the CD4+ T-cell subset from exposed subjects to moDC pulsed with HkBp, LolC or 17 
Rp2 relies on a cell-to-cell contact-dependent pathway.  18 
Selected components of ABC transport systems, especially LolC, have been 19 
demonstrated to induce partial protection when mixed with adjuvant and used to 20 
immunize mice (18), as well as to induce human antigen-specific T-cell responses 21 
(29). Proteins of the tandem repeat family, of which Rp2 is a member, have been 22 
examined as a target for B-cells to produce antibody in certain parasitic infections 23 
(15). We show here for the first time that Rp2 elicits human antigen-specific CD4+ T-24 
 23 
cell responses at least as effectively as LolC and it will be of interest to determine if it 1 
is similarly effective in inducing partial protection against melioidosis in mice. 2 
We used differential expression of CD45RA and CCR7 to characterize the IFN-γ 3 
producing CD4+ T-cells as either central memory (CM), effector memory (EM) or the 4 
more recently described effector memory RA (EMRA) populations (2). By these 5 
criteria, the majority of IFN-γ+CD4+ T-cells reacting to HkBp and LolC were found to 6 
be TEM cells (76% and 73%, respectively), with the remaining minority being TEMRA 7 
and TCM cells. While TCM could provide potentially a rapid function by producing 8 
cytokines that aid generation of TEMRA (14, 33). It is likely that the whole blood assay 9 
may involve distinct T-cell interactions to those detected with antigen-pulsed moDCs.   10 
Although CD4+ T-cells were the dominant producers of IFN-γ in these assays, 11 
heat-killed bacteria and B. pseudomallei Hsp60 were also able to stimulate CD8 T-12 
cells to secrete Granzyme B, an indicator of potential cytotoxic activity.  In 13 
mycobacterial infection, the immunization of mycobacterial Hsp60 induced the 14 
cytotoxic function of CD8+ T-cells specific for mycobacterial Hsp60 (35).  15 
Having provided the first evidence that the B. pseudomallei Rp2 protein is a target 16 
of human cell-mediated responses, we sought to identify Rp peptide epitopes and 17 
determine if they are recognized by co-culture with PBMCs of healthy donors of 18 
varying HLA types living in Northeast Thailand. Five of seven predicted MHC class 19 
II epitopes of Rp stimulated a significant number of IFN-γ-secreting cells. HLA 20 
typing of individuals revealed that 50% of subjects presented heterozygous alleles of 21 
HLA-DR04 and 50% of subjects presented heterozygous alleles of HLA-DR15. The 22 
most common alleles in the NE Thai population include DRB1*1202 and 23 
DRB1*1502 (23). Our results indicate that several Rp epitopes elicit strong IFN-γ 24 
responses from human cellular immunity, across individuals with HLA DR-restricted 25 
 24 
alleles in this small sample size of the Thai population in a Burkholderia endemic 1 
area. 2 
In conclusion, we evaluated the ability of moDC separately pulsed with ten 3 
virulence-associated recombinant proteins of B. pseudomallei to stimulate autologous 4 
human CD4+ T-cell and CD8+ T-cell responses. Our results demonstrate that antigen-5 
specific CD4+ T-cells are generated following exposure of humans to B. pseudomallei 6 
in the environment as they can be stimulated to produce IFN-γ after encountering 7 
moDC pulsed with heat-killed B. pseudomallei or purified proteins, particularly LolC 8 
and Rp2. Antigen-specific CD8+ T-cells are also produced that are a potential source 9 
of IFN-γ and GrB, especially in response to LolC. Our ability to detect human 10 
antigen-specific T-cell responses to defined B. pseudomallei proteins informs the 11 
selection of candidates for inclusion into protein or protein-polysaccharide conjugate 12 
subunit vaccines against this important and emerging infection. Moreover, Rp epitope 13 
sequences analyzed here are conserved across B. pseudomallei, B. thailandensis and 14 
the causative agent of equine glanders B. mallei, suggesting they would have broad 15 
vaccine potential across human and veterinary use for melioidosis and glanders.  16
